Award.AwardTitle: Integration and Curation of the Robert and Virginia Rausch Helminthological Collection- A Resource for Science and Society in the MSB Division of Parasitology
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Robert and Virginia Rausch Helminthological Collection (RHC) is one of the largest parasite collections in the Western Hemisphere and is primarily focused on Arctic and sub-Arctic biomes. It is an irreplaceable resource that documents emerging disease organisms and provides a significant baseline for studies of national interest, including effects of global climate change on fragile northern ecosystems. However, it is an orphaned collection that is in serious jeopardy of total loss without rapid curatorial intervention. This project, centered at the Museum of Southwestern Biology at the University of New Mexico (UNM), will provide personnel, materials and logistical support to insure conservation and permanent housing of RHC specimens. Specimen records, ledgers, and original field notes will be electronically captured, verified, and disseminated broadly via the ARCTOS online database to maximize utility and visibility of the collection.

This project builds on substantial institutional investment and programmatic emphasis in parasitology, diversity of disease organisms, and specimen-based biology at UNM, and provides direct benefit to faculty and students as an education and training resource. Once secured, the RHC will provide unique historical and geographic baselines for bio-monitoring, human health, and global climate change studies. Ultimately, federal support will make this valuable resource available to scientists world-wide via online resources and enhanced access to high-quality specimens and data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Robert and Virginia Rausch Helminthological Collection (RHC) consists of 60,000 lots of valuable and irreplacable parasite and associated mammal and bird specimens.  The RHC provides a picture or snapshot of the world in change (with particular focus on the high northern latitudes), and is a critical part of the framework that makes possible an understanding of how people, animals and disease organisms interact. This collection helps us document, investigate and understand the diverse parasites and pathogens that infect wild and domestic vertebrates, including parasitic worms such as Echinococcus  and Taenia (tapeworms) that annually infect and cause mortality among thousands of people around the globe.  Additional food-borne parasites are especially well represented, including species of Diphyllobothrium (the broad fish tapeworm) that are re-emerging globally where raw fish are major components of the diet. The RHC is further a general historical baseline that tells us about the state of local and regional ecosystems, and provides a unique and necessary tool in recognizing and documenting environmental change due to accelerating climate change and other human activities that can determine the occurrence of invasive species.  Previously this vast collection was unavailable to scientists, managers and public health practitioners. This NSF grant provided the capacity to transfer specimens and detailed data to the Museum of Southwestern Biology (MSB). An unparalleled integrated resource for host and parasite informatics and a cornerstone for studies of disease processes,  now available through the internet, has emerged from the stabilization, curation and digitization of  specimens, and  data  of the RHC. This collection formed a significant basis for the new Division of Parasitology in 2011 at the University of New Mexico which has made a strong commitment to continue and expand studies and education about the associations between hosts and parasites. Explicitly the RHC relates to building a nuanced understanding of the impact of infection and disease for human and animal health, sustainability and safety of food resources, and integrity of natural ecosystems. With the integration of the RHC into MSB, the Division of Parasitology is the third largest parasitic helminth collection in Western Hemisphere museums. The RHC is a core component of one of the most sophisticated, distributed databases for management of natural history collections available globally, significantly expanding the utility of the collection and associated data.
